editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

I Have peru≈øed this Treati≈øe, intituled, The true bounds of Chri≈øtian Freedome, together with the Tran≈ølation of Learned Camerons Tractate, Of the three-fold Covenant, and finding them both to be ≈øolid and judicious, pious and very profitable for the≈øe times, I doe approve and allow them to be printed,

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE EDVVARD Earle of Manche≈øter.
div.p:
TImes of trouble have ever been times of triall, they are ≈øifting times; wherein God ≈øifts us, as he tells us, Amos 9.9. and men ≈øift us; But with a great deale of differrence, God to pre≈øerve the flowre, Men to di≈øcover the bran; the obiect of Gods triall is our graces, of mans our corruptions; that which God aymes at is to evidence our good, that which men, to di≈øcover our evill; your Honour hath pa≈ø≈øed Gods triall, who tries the heart, and the good he hath di≈øcovered, hath rendered you truly honourable: And you have ≈øuffered
mans, I ≈øay ≈øuffered, and to ≈øay no more, have endured the temptation. And indeed your Honour hath been a rock in greater ≈øtormes, and acquitted your ≈øelfe in greater trials then the≈øe are; what are the trials of the≈øe times to the ≈øiftings of former yeares? Then the trials were more clo≈øe, Religion being more ab≈øtracted from other con≈øiderations; now more gro≈ø≈øe being complicated with other re≈øpects; then few would appeare for Religion, though now many ≈øtand up to a≈ø≈øert it; then it was under contempt, now it honours them, who honour it. We reade while iudgements accompanied the Arke of God, while they who had it were ≈ømitten with Emrods, every one thought it a burthen, and were de≈øirous to turne it off; they ≈øent it from Gath, to Ekron, from Ekron to Askalon, and he was the happy man that could rid his hands of it; But afterwards when it came into the hou≈øe of Obed-Edom, and they ≈øaw that God ble≈ø≈øed him and his whole hou≈øe for the Arks ≈øake, then every one could looke upon it as worthy entertainment. While Religion and the truths of God are dangerous and undoing to them
who own them, every one is ≈øhie to receive them, and as ready to reiect them; But when once the wayes of God come to be thriving, enriching and ennobling wayes, and that religion comes to be of common reception, and reputation, then every one is ready to give entertainment to it; It is ≈øomething for a man to owne the Arke when none will own it; indeed many will own a pro≈øpering truth, a ble≈ø≈øing Arke; but he is an Obed-Edom indeed, that will own a per≈øecuted, a to≈ø≈øed, bani≈øhed Arke.

My Lord, you are this Obed-Edom, who have owned the Arke, when few would owne it, that have e≈øteemed it a ble≈ø≈øing, when have apprehended it a cur≈øe, that have looked upon it as your greate≈øt honour when others have eyed it as their di≈øgrace, that have ≈øided with religion not when you might live on it, but when it was to live on you, and upon the be≈øt of your intere≈øts and emjoyments. None that knows your Honour, but knows this, that in the wor≈øt of times, when Religion was under mo≈øt contempt, and it ≈øeemed crime enough to be godly, when your Honour was not onely a carefull
practi≈øer, but a zealous promoter of the wayes of God, a faithfull contender for puritie of doctrine and wor≈øhip, a ≈øhelter to the godly, a refuge to the oppre≈ø≈øed, a fence to religion, and counted godline≈ø≈øe great gaine, when there was (if we looke downward) no gaine to be made of godline≈ø≈øe. And for the publique they are ≈øtrangers in our I≈ørael, that doe not know your con≈øtant and unwearied labours and layings out for it: And before ever the publique was thought upon in publique, even as one, re≈øolved to run that hazzard, either to live in the publique, or to die for the publique. And how God hath carried on your ≈øpirit, and made you ≈øerviceable in the≈øe times of common calamity, not Epi≈øtles, but Chronicles, without ≈øuf≈øpition of partialitie ≈øhall report to future generations, when all clouds of mi≈øtake ≈øhall vani≈øh, and nothing but impartiall truth ≈øhall be revealed.

To you my honoured Lord, as to one who hath been ≈øo zealous an A≈ø≈øertor of liberties, this ≈ømall Treati≈øe of Chri≈øtian Libertie flyes for protection, not that it feares injury, if innocency may ≈øecure it, but de≈øires Patronage of them who are
worthy: It contains chiefly ≈øome friendly debates of ≈øome opinions, which have been maintained again≈øt the Law, wherein I have ≈øo endeavoured to hold up the Law, as not to intrench upon the liberties of Grace, and ≈øo to e≈øtabli≈øh grace, as not to make void the Law, nor to di≈øcharge beleevers of any dutie they owe to God or man. And this di≈øcour≈øe though weak, yet ≈øuch as it is, I make bold to pre≈øent to your Honour with your vertuous and noble Lady, and ≈øhould onely convey it into your bo≈øomes by prayer, did not my native Countrey and place to which your Honour is related, Manche≈øter. ingage me to adde a few words. A place it is which above many others God hath honoured both in ≈øtrengthening them to doe their duty, and pre≈øerving them in it, making them not onely a Rock again≈øt their enemies, but a refuge for their friends, the releevers of many places in danger, and the recoverers of many lo≈øt; It is my earne≈øt reque≈øt to your Honour as bearing relation to them, that while they are in conflict, they may be eyed and relieved; And when it ≈øhall plea≈øe God the ≈øtorme is over, your Honour would looke upon that place, in helping
to adde to the honour of your name upon it, ≈øome further name of honour to it; And the God of all grace and mercy be ≈øtill a tower of protection to them, and a ≈øtarre of direction to you, that you may know how to walke in wi≈ødome under all the changes of his providence to you, and make your Honour yet further in≈øtrumentall, to advance his cau≈øe, and promote his glory, and when you have ≈øerved him in your generation here, take you to his glory hereafter; which is the earne≈øt and heartie prayer of him,

closer.signed: Who≈øe all is but to ≈øerve you in Chri≈øt, SAMUEL BOLTON.

div.head: To the Chri≈øtian Reader.
div.p:
THou art not I conceive ≈øuch a ≈øtranger to the≈øe times but thou knowe≈øt, that as God hath communicated many truths; ≈øo hath Satan ≈øought to vent many errors; Hereby labouring to prejudice and weaken the reception of the one, if hee could not prevaile to the entertainment of the other. Indeed it is his be≈øt ≈øea≈øon for merchandizing, at ≈øuch a time he finds mo≈øt Chapmen, and in the heat of the Market while men are buying truths, he may hope to put off ≈øome of his own wares; which that he may make more vendible, he will ≈øeeke to pa≈ø≈øe them under as honourable notions, and not ≈øtick to language them into your hearts under as ≈øpirituall conceptions, as truth it ≈øelfe. He hath a long time walked as a prince of darkne≈ø≈øe, and becau≈øe he can deceive no longer in that ≈øhape, he now transformes him≈øelfe into an Angel of light. He went a long time bare-faced, and was ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull; when he was di≈øcovered he put on a
mask, under which he hath walked many generations. And that being taken off al≈øo, he now di≈ø≈øembles the very vi≈øage of truth: Of all errours, none are more ≈øeductive then ≈øuch which are handed to men under the notions of Free Grace, and none more de≈øtructive, they are poy≈øon in the heart, poy≈øon in the fountaine. I need not tell thee how many of this kinde have been vented, and entertained. For the reducing of tho≈øe who are carryed away, the e≈øtabli≈øhing of tho≈øe who ≈øtagger, and the building up of tho≈øe who are in ≈øome mea≈øure ≈øettled in the truth; this following Treati≈øe being fir≈øt preached (through the long and earne≈øt importunitie of many friends) is now Printed.

The ≈øubject Whereon this Di≈øcour≈øe is founded, Dr. Cri≈øp in his Chri≈øt alone exalted: weth others. is the ≈øame which is made the foundation of theirs, which I cho≈øe the rather, that it might be evidenced to all who≈øe ≈øuper-≈øtructure did mo≈øt re≈øemble the foundation; the Di≈øcour≈øe it ≈øelfe is partly Doctrinall, wherein the received truth is laid down and confirmed; partly Controver≈øall, wherein the contrary Opinions are examined, and confuted.

Fir≈øt I ≈øay examined, and we have given them a fair triall, being willing to heare
the utmo≈øt they could ≈øay. This examination lyes in ≈øixe Queries. viz.
1. Query. Whether this be any part of our freedome by Chri≈øt to be freed from the Law.
2. Query. Whether this be any part of our freedome by Chri≈øt, to be free from all puni≈øhments or cha≈øti≈øements for ≈øinne.
3. Query. Whether this may con≈øi≈øt with our Chri≈øtian freedome, to be tyed to doe dutie becau≈øe God hath commanded.
4. Query. Whether the free men of Chri≈øt, may not ≈øin them≈øelves into bondage again.
5. Query. Whether this may con≈øi≈øt with our Chri≈øtian freedome, to do duties with a re≈øpect to the recompence of reward.
6. Query. Whether this be part of our freedome by Chri≈øt, to be freed from obedience unto men.

The≈øe are the maine inquiries, in which thou may≈øt al≈øo read the contrary Doctrins which are now held forth by many, as plainly confuted, as friendly debated; In which Work my maine end hath been to convince the iudgement, not to irritate the affections,
le≈øt while I ≈øought to be helpfull to grace, I might be ≈øerviceable to ≈øinne, and whil≈øt I indeavoured to cheri≈øh mens holine≈ø≈øe, I ≈øhould but draw out mens corruptions, and ≈øo run in vaine. And therefore I have de≈øired to deale with things, more then per≈øons; and rather to di≈øcover errours by Arguments, then by names. And it is my earne≈øt de≈øire that what is here made obvious to thine eye, the God of truth would make evident to thy heart, and give unto thee and me ≈øound judgement, that we may be able to di≈øcerne of things that differ, guide us in the wayes of faith and obedience, inable us to ≈øerve him while we live, ≈ømile upon us when we die, and after death take us to him≈øelfe; which is the all I can de≈øire for my ≈øelfe, and the lea≈øt I will de≈øire for thee, who am

closer.signed: Thine in the ≈øervice of Chri≈øt to advance faith and obedience, SAMUEL BOLTON.

div.p:
IT is ≈øet down as a part of the ≈øufferings of Chri≈øt, Hebr. 12.3. that he endured the contradiction of ≈øinners. And among all the Chapters in the Go≈øpel, there is none that ≈øets down ≈øo great a part of the ≈øufferings of Chri≈øt in this

And having ≈øhewed them their pre≈øent ≈øinfull condition, hee comes to tell them what ≈øhal be their future doome, they mu≈øt be ca≈øt out of the hou≈øe, though they were now in the Church of God, yet they ≈øhould not continue in it, they mu≈øt be ca≈øt out, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, Gal. div.p:
And in this you have the whole Text.
The Benefit freedome: The Qualitie of it, true and reall: The Subiects of it, true Beleevers; and the Author of it, Chri≈øt. If the Sonne ≈øhall make you free, then ‚Äî All which makes this one Conclu≈øion, That there is a true and reall freedome.
Now in the pro≈øecution of this, we ≈øhall indeavour to do the≈øe three things. And ≈øo come to the An≈øwer of tho≈øe Queries which induced me to enter upon this Di≈øcour≈øe.

And this briefly, that ≈øo we may come to that which I have chiefly intended.

1. For the nature of it, what freedome that is for kinde, of which Chri≈øt doth here ≈øpeake, and into which Chri≈øt doth in≈øtate Beleevers. For the clearing of which, it is needfull to tell you that there are foure kinds of freedome.
1. A naturall freedome. 2. Politicall. 3. Sen≈øuall. 4. Spirituall.
Fir≈øt, A Naturall freedome, ≈øuch a freedome as is in every thing by nature, every thing in nature injoyes a naturall freedome: but of this it is not ≈øpoken.

Secondly, There is a Politicall freedome, which is freedome of ≈øuch a Nation, ≈øuch a State, ≈øuch a Commonwealth, and Corporation; and of this the Iewes thought Chri≈øt ≈øpake; they were Abrahams ≈øeed, and therefore free; but of this Chri≈øt did not ≈øpeake.

Thirdly, There is a corrupt and ≈øinfull freedome, which we expre≈ø≈øe under the word Libertini≈øme: and the Apo≈øtle ≈øets downe in the 5. Gal. 13. Brethren ye are called unto libertie; but u≈øe not libertie as an occa≈øion to the fle≈øh; that is, as an occa≈øion to ≈øinne; this is fearefull, to turne the grace of God into wantonne≈ø≈øe, of whom the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh in the fourth of Iude, There are certaine men creept in unawares, who were of old ordained to the condemnation, ungodly men, turning the grace of God into la≈øciviou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

≈øinne, to doe any act of maliciou≈øne≈ø≈øe, but much more to cloake it, cover it; and much more againe to make Chri≈øtian libertie the cloake of ≈øinne, that is mo≈øt damnable; to make Religion, to make the truth of God, to make Chri≈øtian liberty ≈øo dearely purcha≈øed, a cloake or pretence to ≈øinne; or to take occa≈øion to ≈øinne by it, is a fearefull ≈øinne.

Fourthly, There is a ≈øpirituall and heavenly freedome; a freedome purcha≈øed by Chri≈øt, revealed in the Go≈øpel, conveyed to the Saints, as the great dowry of Chri≈øt to his Church and Spou≈øe.

There are two great things Chri≈øt hath intru≈øted into the hands of his Church: Fir≈øt, Chri≈øtian faith. Secondly, Chri≈øtian liberty. And as we are to contend earne≈øtly for the maintenance of the faith, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, Jude 3. Iude 3. So al≈øo for the maintenance of Chri≈øtian libertie, Gal. 5.1. again≈øt all oppugners and underminers of it. Gal. 5.1. Stand fa≈øt in the libertie wherewith Chri≈øt made you free. In the generall then I ≈øay, the freedome into which Chri≈øt hath in≈øtated beleevers, is a ≈øpirituall, a divine freedome; a freedome in oppo≈øition to our former bondage. Which clearely under≈øtood, would di≈øcover what our freedome is. We come to the ≈øecond.
Secondly, What is the quality of this freedome?
There is one qualitie in the Text: I ≈øhall but adde two more to it.

Fir≈øt, It is a reall freedome, not an imaginary, not a fancied freedome; there are too many who are imaginary free, and really in bondage: But this is no imaginarie freedome; it is a freedome indeed, a true and reall freedome, whom the Sonne makes free are free indeed.

Secondly, It is an univer≈øall freedome: a freedome which leaves us in no part of bondage: that look what ever was any part of our bondage before; in our liberty now, we are freed from it. We ≈øhall ≈øpeake chiefly to the fir≈øt: the freedome of Saints here in Grace, which is our inchoate freedome. And we will briefly lay down the parts of it, which are two

Chri≈øt invites men unto the Kingdome of heaven (that is, the Evangelicall admini≈øtration of his Church,) as being that, that was even now at hand, and ≈øhould ≈øhortly be, but as yet was not pre≈øent; yea verily, ≈øeeing hee was even now rai≈øed from the dead, although you heare him openly profe≈ø≈øing to his Apo≈øtles, Mat. 28.18 That all power was given him both in heaven and in earth, and commanding them to preach the Go≈øpel unto every creature, yet hee doth ≈øo command this, Luke 24.49. as he biddeth them to expect at Ieru≈øalem, the fulfilling of the promi≈øe concerning the ≈øolemne Mi≈ø≈øion of the holy Gho≈øt [unto them] as being indeed de≈øigned already, but then at length to be in≈øtall'd and publikely receiv'd with extraordinary ≈øignes, whil≈øt many ≈øhould both heare it, and ≈øtand lookers on.

div.head: 41. The≈øis.
div.p:
Here [now] would be a fit place wherein to ≈øpeak more at large concerning the excellency of this Covenant, but ≈øeeing the matter otherwi≈øe in it ≈øelfe is not ob≈øcure; and in comparing it with the Covenant of Nature, we have already
touched many things belonging to this place, wee will for ≈øo long defer the matter, untill we ≈øhall undertake to ≈øhew you the compari≈øon betweene this and the Old Covenant, (which wee call by this name a ≈øub≈øervient Covenant) of which I am now purpo≈øed to ≈øpeak.

div.head: 42. The≈øis.
div.p: The Old Covenant, The old Covenant what it is. or the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant, we call that, which God entred into with the people of I≈ørael in the mount Sinai, that he might prepare them for faith, and that he might enflame them, with a de≈øire of the promi≈øe, and of the Go≈øpel-Covenant, which otherwi≈øe had died and langui≈øhed in their mindes, [hearts,] and that withall he might, as with a curb re≈øtraine them from their impieties, even untill that very time: wherein he was purpo≈øed to ≈øend the Spirit of Adoption into their hearts, and to governe them by the law of libertie.

div.head: 43. The≈øis.
div.p:
Hence we ≈øuppo≈øe, that it is not ob≈øcure, Why it is called ≈øub≈øervient. why it is by us called a ≈øub≈øervient Covenant, wel-neer in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, wherein it is called by the Holy Gho≈øt, the old Covenant, not becau≈øe it is the fir≈øt (as ≈øome doe ≈øurmi≈øe) but in that it ought to wax
old, Heb. 8.13 and to give place to a better Covenant, which is to ≈øucceed it, and ≈øo it ≈øelfe at length to be aboli≈øhed.

div.head: 44. The≈øis.
div.p: The nature and condition of this Covenant, cannot be more certainely ≈øought, or more ea≈øily found [out,] then by comparing it, fir≈øt with the Covenant of Nature; and after that, with the Covenant of Grace; for it will ≈øo come to pa≈ø≈øe, by this ≈øearch, that all tho≈øe things being weighed, wherein it doth agree with tho≈øe other Covenants, all its properties wil be brought forth to light.

div.head: 45. The≈øis.
div.p: It agrees with the Covenant of Nature. The agreement of the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant, and the Covenant of Nature. Fir≈øt, for that in both [the≈øe Covenants] the one part contracting, [or Covenanting] is God, the other is man. Secondly, that both have their ≈øtipulation or condition annexed. Thirdly, that the ≈øtipulation is the ≈øame, as touching the Morall law. Fourthly, that the promi≈øe is the ≈øame in the generall. Fifthly, for that both of them do lead us unto Chri≈øt.

div.head: 46. The≈øis.
div.p:
But they differ. The difference. Fir≈øt, in that the Covenant of Nature was made altogether with all men, this only with the I≈øraelites.
Secondly, in that the Covenant of Nature was pre≈øently made wth man, at the in≈øtaÃÑt of his Creation, and had no praeparatories at all unto it; the old Covenant long after, and had many praeparatories. Thirdly, that the Covenant of Nature doth onely binde us by the law of Nature unto due obedience. The old covenant doth oblige us farther, unto ceremonies. Fourthly, ≈øeeing life is promi≈øed in both Covenants, in this, it is de≈øigned us, by the fruition of the land of Canaan, in that of Paradi≈øe. Fiftly, ≈øeeing both covenants do lead us unto Chri≈øt, the covenant of nature doth not this by it ≈øelf, but by accident, the old covenant doth this by it ≈øelf; for it is its true and proper ≈øcope: For God made not the Covenant of Nature with men, for this end, that being oppre≈ø≈øed with the weight of it, they ≈øhould breath after Chri≈øt, but the la≈øt and maine end of it is this, that men ≈øhould render up unto God that which is his due; but in the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant, God requires not his right, for any other end then this, that men, upon conviction of their owne weakne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould flie into the armes of Chri≈øt. Sixtly, the Covenant of Nature, is founded upon the Creation and generall Con≈øervation, the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant is founded upon the Election of the people of
I≈ørael. And la≈øtly upon their freedom out of Egypt, and their con≈øervation in the land of Canaan. Seventhly, the Covenant of Nature was therefore made, that by it men might be drawn ≈øweetly, for it was written in their hearts, but the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant for this end, to compell men, Gal. 4.24. for it did beget unto bondage. Eightly, the Covenant of Nature is eternall, the old Covenant is but temporary. Ninthly, the Covenant of Nature had no regard unto re≈øtraint from outward impieties, neither as touching the principall ≈øcope of it, nor yet as touching the le≈ø≈øe principall. Ex. 20.20. The old Covenant as touching its le≈ø≈øe principall ≈øcope hereunto hath regard. Tenthly, the Covenant of Nature was engraven in the heart, whereas the old Covenant only in tables of ≈øtone. Eleaventhly, the Covenant of Nature was made in Paradi≈øe, the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant in the Mount Sinai. Twelfthly, there was no Mediatour, of the Covenant of Nature; the ≈øub≈øervient Covenant had a Mediatour, that is to ≈øay, Mo≈øes. Thirteenthly, the Covenant of Nature was made with man, perfect and in innocency, the Sub≈øervient Covenant, only with ≈øome part of mankinde being lap≈øed.

div.head: 47. The≈øis.
div.p: Here it may be asked, fir≈øt of all, how we are drawn by the Covenant of nature unto Chri≈øt, by accident, for we ≈øaid, but now, that it was not ordained mainly for this end. Secondly, how the Covenant of Nature may be ≈øaid to draw men ≈øweetly, ≈øince it doth compell rather? Thirdly, ≈øeeing then it doth compell, in what ≈øen≈øe or con≈øideration, as touching this part of it, it may be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Sub≈øervient Covenant.

div.head: 48. The≈øis.
div.p: To the fir≈øt I An≈øwer. The Covenant of Nature leadeth unto Chri≈øt. The Covenant of Nature brings men by accident unto Chri≈øt, in that it ≈øhewed what man is indebted unto God, and how ≈øore puni≈øhment abideth him, who doth not pay this debt; whence it compels a man to looke to the Mediatour, ≈øeeing he beholds him≈øelf both unable to di≈øcharge the debt, and as unable every whit to undergoe the puni≈øhment.

div.head: 49. The≈øis.
div.p:
Neverthele≈ø≈øe, This it doth diver≈øe wayes. it doth not this alike in all men, for in tho≈øe who are guided only by the light of Nature, by rea≈øon of that ignorance which is ingenerated in the minde of man; it performes this more ≈øuperficially
and ≈ølightly: but tho≈øe now who in the word of God doe read this due of nature; or heare it deciphered; it doth urge more ≈øtrongly: But mo≈øt of all ≈øtrongly, tho≈øe, who≈øe minds it doth Luce perfundit. be≈øprinkle or inlighten with a ≈øingular and extraordinary light, to di≈øcerne clearely how much it is they owe, and how little they have payed; as al≈øo how ≈øore a puni≈øhment they have, upon that account, demerited.

div.head: 50. The≈øis.
div.p: Yet this was not the end of this Covenant; By the Covenant of Nature, men are re≈øtrained from ≈øinne. never thele≈ø≈øe, in that the knowledge thereof was not wholly blotted out of the minde of lap≈øed men, it was ≈øo ordained of God for this end, that thereto it might be ≈øerviceable, both to re≈øtraine men, and to lead them unto Chri≈øt.

div.p: And al≈øo tho≈øe very things, which by accident the Covenant of Nature doth effect, yet it doth effect them after another manner, then the Sub≈øervient Covenant doth.

div.p:
For fir≈øt, And by the Sub≈øervient Covenant. in that the Covenant of Nature doth re≈øtraine men from externall vices, this it doth, not for any want of the Spirits being powred forth, under the New
Te≈øtament, (whereto the re≈øtraint, that flowes from the Sub≈øervient Covenant did referre) but this it did, before that fulne≈ø≈øe of times, for want of the Spirit, which tho≈øe times did partake of; and ≈øince the promulgation of the Go≈øpel, it doth the ≈øame thing al≈øo, for want of the Spirit, which was promi≈øed in the new Covenant. But in what the Sub≈øervient Covenant did re≈øtraine, that it did, becau≈øe the time was not as yet come: wherein God would ≈øend the Spirit of Adoption into the hearts of his faithfull ones.

div.head: 53. The≈øis.
div.p:
For like as under the New Te≈øtament, the mea≈øure of the Spirit is one in this life, another in the life to come; ≈øo under the Old Te≈øtament, the mea≈øure of the Spirit was farre different then from what now it is under the New: and like as in that mea≈øure of the Spirit, which is be≈øtowed under the New Te≈øtament, ≈øeeing in this life it is not be≈øtowed perfect, there is need of a curbe whereby the fle≈øh might be re≈øtrained, which is the Covenant of Nature; ≈øo that mea≈øure which could be afforded us in the Old Covenant, for as

div.p: For this cau≈øe the Iewes, both by the Covonant of Nature, like unto us, and al≈øo by the Sub≈øervient Covenant, different from us, were re≈øtrained from externall ≈øinnes.

div.p: In like manner al≈øo doth the Covenant of Nature lead us unto Chri≈øt one way, Men are otherwi≈øe drawn unto Chri≈øt by the Covenant of Nature, otherwi≈øe by the Sub≈øervient Covenant. the Sub≈øervient Covenant another: for the Covenant of Nature begets and ≈øtirres up thir≈øt in men; which by Chri≈øt applyed, either in the promi≈øe, or the Go≈øpel, is a≈ø≈øwaged; but the thir≈øt which the Sub≈øervient Covenant did excite, could be no otherwi≈øe a≈ø≈øwaged, then by the coming of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe in the fle≈øh.

div.p:
Therefore men, ≈øo farre forth as being pre≈ø≈øed on by the Covenant of Nature, they are di≈øquieted with the de≈øire of a Mediatour; yet before he was exhibited, they de≈øire only an Application of Chri≈øt promi≈øed, but after he was exhibited, they de≈øire the be≈øtowing of him exhibited. But the Sub≈øervient Covenant

Iu≈øt thus under the Go≈øpel, the Covenant of Grace doth ca≈øt in a de≈øire, not only of that mea≈øure of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which will be afforded us in this life, but it doth al≈øo excite and ≈øtirre up, in the minds of the godly, a marvellous de≈øire of the di≈ø≈øolution of this body, and of the ≈øecond comming of Chri≈øt.

To the Third we have already an≈øwered, (above, in The≈øis 52, 53.) where we explained how men might one way be

div.p:
This ≈øo comes to pa≈ø≈øe, when what we hate in it ≈øelfe, our wils doe yet embrace, either for the avoydance of ≈øomething, which we more hate; or for the atchievement of ≈øomething, the love of which

div.head: 69. The≈øis.

There are two parts of the old Covenant, the Law Morall, and Ceremoniall, The u≈øe of the Law, Morall and Ceremoniall. to which al≈øo may be added their Polity: [namely, the Iudiciall Law] the≈øe, if con≈øidered in them≈øelves, did redargue and reprove man of ≈øinne; and indeed the Morall Law, as through the weakene≈ø≈øe of the fle≈øh it is impo≈øsible; ≈øo it declares a man not to be ≈øpirituall, and it doth re≈øtraine him from outward impieties, through the intervening of the ≈øpirit of bondage Heb. 10.3.; but now the Ceremonies did ≈øet forth mans impuritie contracted by ≈øinne. But and if we con≈øider them as Types, ≈øo the Morall Law was the Copy

div.head: 71. The≈øis.
div.p: Here two things will be demanded: Fir≈øt, how Mo≈øes could be ≈øaid to be a Mediatour of that covenant, ≈øeeing he him≈øelfe was one included in the party on the one ≈øide covenanting. Secondly, why the Sacrifices, [Sacraments] and Ceremonies of the Old Covenant, are called carnall Heb. 9.10.; the Sacraments of the New Covenant not ≈øo; whereas Chri≈øt, or the benefits of Chri≈øt were repre≈øented as well in tho≈øe, [of the Old Covenant] as in the≈øe they are.

div.head: 72. The≈øis.
div.p:
To the fir≈øt, How Mo≈øes could be a Mediatour. I An≈øwer. It is not ab≈øurd, that both one and the ≈øame, under a divers con≈øideration, may be both a Mediatour, and may yet be one included in party of the one ≈øide, Covenanting. For in the New Covenant, Chri≈øt, though he
be a Mediatour; yet as God, he likewi≈øe is the other party covenanting; ≈øo in the Old Covenant Mo≈øes, ≈øeeing he was an I≈øraelite, and a part of that people with whom God did enter into covenant, after he had taken upon him the Office of a Mediatour, appointed him by God; he is no longer now ≈øimply to be con≈øidered as an I≈øraelite, but as a Mediatour; making interce≈øsion betweene God and the people of I≈ørael; and this we conceive was done, that ≈øo he might appeare to be a clearer and more manife≈øt Type of Chri≈øt.

div.head: 73. The≈øis.
div.p:
But from hence a greater and more weighty difficultie ≈øeemeth to ari≈øe: for ≈øeeing God is infinite, it may not ab≈øurdly be demanded, In what respect could Mo≈øes be a Mediatour betweene God and man, ≈øeeing he him≈øelfe was but a man? To this we an≈øwer: that Mediation is twofold. The one, by the benefit whereof men are truely and effectually united unto God; and this Mediation we confe≈ø≈øe, belongeth to no other then to a per≈øon indued with infinite vertue and power; and ≈øo that the New Covenant could admit of no other Mediatour then of one,
